designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) to the Government of Cambodia aims to improve aid 
effectiveness through greater use of government systems for the management and utilization of 
its  portfolio  of  externally  financed  projects  and  programs.  Based  on  the  findings  and 
recommendations  of  the  2012  country  portfolio  review  mission  (CPRM)  of  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB), the 2012 Joint Country Portfolio Performance Review (JCPPR),1 and 
the  government's  2011  Cambodia  Development  Effectiveness  Report, 2  the  government 
requested ADB assistance in building its capacity to manage ADB-financed projects in particular 
and official development assistance in general. The TA concept paper was approved on 19 April 
2012. The scope, expected impact, outcome, outputs, and implementation arrangements were 
discussed and finalized during the TA fact-finding mission in April 2012.3  
 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Official development assistance contributes about 50% of the government's budget and 
is an important catalyst for Cambodia’s rapid economic development; sustainable economic 
growth is projected at 7% annually during the implementation period of the National Strategic 
Development Plan, 2009–2013. As one of Cambodia’s largest development partners, ADB has 
provided 78 public sector loans or grants for a total of $1.5 billion, and annual approvals of new 
projects or programs planned for 2013–2014 amounting to about $130 million. The total current 
volume of ADB’s active loan and grant portfolio is $772.7 million, but the size of the portfolio is 
rapidly expanding and may reach $900 million in 2012. To ensure sustained economic growth, 
the government will need to better manage its public investments, cut procurement delays, and 
improve its business procedures. 
 
3.   The CPRM concluded that a substantial improvement of portfolio performance requires 
long-term, well-structured capacity development of executing and implementing agencies in 
project management, procurement, and financial management. The most suitable avenue to 
pursue this is through the country's own systems of project management, financial management, 
and procurement for externally financed projects. These are enshrined and described in detail in 
the  government's  standard  operating  procedure  (SOP)  for  processing,  implementing,  and 
completing projects. 
 
4.  Prior to 2005, the government did not have a coherent, consistent, and unified set of 
operating  procedures  to  manage  and  implement  externally  financed  projects.  With  the 
assistance of ADB, the government in 2005 developed and issued instructions to implement 
(i) a  SOP  manual  on  project  administration  to  increase  aid  effectiveness  and  improve 
management  of  the  externally  assisted  portfolio;  (ii)  a  procurement  manual  to  improve 
procurement performance of the portfolio; and (iii) a financial management manual (FMM) to 
develop  and  maintain  effective  and  efficient  financial  management  of  projects.  This 
demonstrated the government’s strong commitment to principles of the 2005 Paris Declaration 
on Aid Effectiveness. The three manuals were promulgated under a Sub Decree on 22 May 
2012, making their use mandatory for all externally assisted projects and programs in Cambodia 
under the purview of the Ministry of Economy and Finance (MEF).  
 
                                                 
1 Led by the Ministry of Economy and Finance and involving ADB, Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA), 
and the World Bank. 
2  Royal Government of Cambodia. 2011. Cambodia Development Effectiveness Report. Phnom Penh.

5.  While the use of the manuals was made mandatory, capacity building to ensure effective 
implementation was not organized in any structured and sustainable manner. The JCPPR found 
that the lack of institutionalized training was a major obstacle to providing regular training on 
procurement and financial management, and improving portfolio performance. A JCPPR action 
plan  was  prepared  in  April  2012,  which  included  a  proposal  to  prepare  and  implement  a 
structured capacity building program to improve aid utilization efficiency. 
 
6.  Since 2010, all JCPPR partners have supported MEF in updating the three manuals. 
ADB provided extensive support using project grant resources managed by the Cambodia 
Resident Mission and ADB's Southeast Asia Department.4 It is the government’s intention to 
mandate the application of the manuals to all projects and programs financed by development 
partners starting in second-half of 2012. To ensure successful implementation, a well-structured 
capacity development program for staff at executing and implementing agencies is needed. 
 
7.  While SOP and FMM describe the prevailing country systems on project administration 
and financial management (there are no other equivalent regulations), the regulations governing 
procurement are more complex. The January 2012 Law on Public Procurement is guided by a 
Sub Decree—Internal Rules and Regulations governing Public Procurement (IRRPP)—covering 
domestically funded procurement. The law and the IRRPP are not yet officially translated into 
English but the IRRPP appears to be closely aligned with the provisions in the procurement 
manual, with only minor differences. This effectively means that there are two parallel country 
procurement  systems  (one  for  domestic  procurement  and  one  for  projects  funded  by  the 
development partners). The law covers both systems and specifies that externally financed 
projects can use the procurement manual if the financing agreements state that it will apply. 
Thus, the government currently applies parallel procurement systems that are both mandatory 
for government agencies, depending on the source of financing.  
 
8.  The medium-term goal for the government is to unify the IRRPP and the procurement 
manual,  probably  by  subsuming  the  IRRPP  into  the  manual.  As  an  interim  measure,  the 
government seeks to strengthen the capacity of staff who are users of the manual through an 
extensive training and certification program. In effect, the procurement training will benefit a 
large majority of project implementation units in Cambodia, irrespective of whether the projects 
are  funded  by  development  partners  or  the  government’s  own  resources.  The  reality  in 
Cambodia is that most government procurement officers in line ministries are dealing with both 
types of projects anyway.  
 
9.  The  TA  will  support  the  government’s  priorities  of  implementing  an  ongoing  public 
financial management reform program and its Aid Management Policy. It will also support the 
government’s commitments under the Paris Declaration and the Busan Outcome Statement 
(2011) to strengthen its country systems to a standard that will allow greater utilization by the 
development partners. 
 
10.  Capacity building will be implemented in two phases. The first will focus on accelerated 
training on the procurement manual, on the use of SOP for project administration, and the use 
of the FMM for executing and implementing agencies of externally assisted projects. Phase 1 
will also include a training-of-trainers (TOT) program and an interim certification program for the 
trainees. Phase 2 (to be implemented in 2015) will create an institutionalized professional 
training and certification program in procurement, likely to be executed by the Department of 
Public Procurement of MEF. The government will seek separate funding for phase 2 from other

3   
development partners. Phase 1 will thus closely involve the Department of Public Procurement 
and development partners to ensure that institutional arrangements for phase 2 can be finalized 
by the end of phase 1. 
 
11.  Lessons from previous capacity development efforts include the need for government 
staff to train other government staff under a TOT program. This arrangement will contribute to 
ensuring long-term sustainability of domestic training capacity by building a pool of talented 
procurement and financial management trainers. The Economics and Finance Institute under 
MEF,  which  is  mandated  to  train  public  civil  servants  in  the  areas  of  public  finance  and 
economics, is presently involved in training 500–1,000 public servants annually under a multi-
donor trust fund project managed by the World Bank.5 It is therefore considered an appropriate 
institution to implement the TOT program.  
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
12.  The impact of the TA will be greater aid effectiveness through better use of government 
systems. The outcome will be strengthened capacity of government officials for procurement, 
financial management, and project administration to better implement externally funded projects 
and programs that are guided by the SOP, procurement manual, and FMM.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
13.  The TA will support development and implementation of (i) a TOT program to build the 
capacity of government trainers to help deliver training workshops; (ii) accelerated training on 
procurement, financial management, and project administration; and (iii) an interim certification 
program for project managers, procurement officers, and finance officers. The activities are 
outlined below. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
14.   Training of trainers. The main purpose of this program is to train 10 public officers with 
experience in procurement and 15 with experience in financial management as trainers and 
resource persons who will assist the training consultants in the various training workshops. The 
candidates will be selected from among those officers who have a proven record of successfully 
implementing externally financed projects. Recommendations will be sought from project team 
leaders of ADB, Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA), and the World Bank to ensure 
quality selection. The 10 candidates for the procurement and 15 candidates for the financial 
management TOT will be selected from within MEF and other government entities. An additional 
20  will  be  chosen  by  a  selection  committee  with  the  assistance  of  the  external  training 
consultants. MEF will use its own resources to pay stipends to the trainers in line with practices 
applied under similar MEF-led training programs. The selected officers will undergo intensive 
training on the updated SOP, procurement manual, and FMM (as applicable) in four training 
sessions of 5 working days each. The trainers, after completing training and testing, will be 
officially accredited by MEF. 
 
15.  Accelerated training. Government project managers and key procurement and finance 
staff from all ministries assigned to implement externally funded projects or programs guided by 
the manuals will be trained in a modular format. Consultants recruited for this purpose will 
                                                 
5 World Bank. 2005. Public Financial Management and Accountability Project. Washington, DC (TF054547).

4   
develop three modules covering SOP, procurement manual, and FMM. Modular training will 
include 18 workshops each in 2013 and 2014, to be held in a province outside Phnom Penh. 
After a quick training needs assessment, the consultants will prepare training materials, a 
detailed training program for both years, and the criteria for selecting the trainees, and will then 
conduct the training workshops. The workshops will be offered regularly for groups of 20, each 
workshop lasting up to 5 working days per module. All groups will be required to go through all 
the modules. It is envisaged that nine groups will be trained in the first year, and nine groups in 
the second year. The achievements of the training will be evaluated throughout the program by 
an independent evaluator. Also, periodic surveys among supervisors of the trainees will be 
conducted to ensure that the training program remains relevant. The 2-year training program will 
be the starting point for a full-fledged training and certification program under phase 2 for 
government  officers  working  on  externally  funded  and  government-financed  projects.  All 
activities will be carefully designed to ensure that phases 1 and 2 are linked. Phase 2 will 
introduce an internationally recognized body to independently perform accreditations with due 
consideration to performance management and compliance systems to sustain the merits of the 
certification program. 
 
16.  Interim certification program. This will enable staff to attain recognition of their skills. It 
will also provide a level of comfort to the management of executing and implementing agencies 
that staff with the right skills fill the important positions of project manager, procurement officer, 
and finance officer. The interim certification program will be offered for a transitory period until a 
more robust and long-term professional development program is established under phase 2, for 
which JICA initially expressed interest in funding. The finance officers will be tested on their 
knowledge  of  the  updated  SOP,  FMM,  and  general  principles  of  procurement,  while  the 
procurement officers will be tested on the provisions of the updated procurement manual and 
ability to carry out procurement tasks. The training will also enable staff to better understand the 
differences between (i) the SOP; (ii) ADB, JICA, and World Bank guidelines; and (iii) the IRRPP. 
Consultants will develop the certification program and the assessment procedures. MEF will 
issue  the  interim  certifications.  Approaches  being  applied  in  ADB's  ongoing  in-house 
Procurement Accreditation Skills Scheme may be integrated into the program. The output will 
also  prepare  for  phase  2,  where  an  internationally  recognized  body  will  put  in  place  a 
comprehensive accreditation program to ensure sustainability of the certification program. 
  
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
17.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,100,000 million, of which $1,000,000 will be financed on 
a  grant  basis  by  the  Japan  Fund  for  Poverty  Reduction  and  administered  by  ADB.  The 
government  will  provide  staff  time  and  allowances,  office  accommodation,  transport,  and 
stipends. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. All disbursements under the 
TA will be done in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, 
as amended from time to time). 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  MEF will be the executing agency. A project management office will be set up under the 
Department of Investment and Cooperation to manage day-to-day TA activities. The TA team 
will work closely with MEF’s Department of Public Procurement to ensure harmonization with 
the Public Procurement Law and the Public Financial Management Reform Secretariat. The TA 
team will also work with MEF’s subcommittee on capacity building to align the TA with the 
implementation of the government-led public financial management reform program, and with

5   
the Economics and Finance Institute or a similar body to deliver the TOT activities in phase 1 
and to ensure a link to phase 2, with a focus on establishing a learning institution in Cambodia. 
 
19.  The TA will require (i) 26 person-months of international consultant inputs—procurement 
training and certification expert (9 person-months intermittent), financial management expert 
(8 person-months intermittent), project management expert (6 person-months intermittent), and 
training  evaluator  (3 person-months  intermittent)—and  (ii)  48  person-months  of  national 
consultant inputs—procurement expert (12 person-months intermittent), financial management 
expert  (12  person-months  intermittent),  and  training  coordinator  (24  person-months).  All 
consultants will be based within the executing agency.  
 
20.  The consultants will be recruited individually by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The outline terms of reference 
of the consultants are in Appendix 3. Office equipment totaling not more than $30,000 will be 
procured in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to 
time). The equipment will be handed over to the executing agency upon completion of the TA. 
The executing agency will administer expenses for training and workshops via an advance 
payment facility. The executing agency has sufficient capacity to complete the activity and 
liquidate the advance. Individual consultants are preferred since they can be mobilized faster 
than  firms;  the  work  they  undertake  is  not  dependent  on  the  outputs  produced  by  other 
consultants. The executing agency will be subject to a strict performance monitoring system, 
and staff from ADB's Cambodia Resident Mission will supervise the TA implementation. These 
are important lessons learned from past TA projects. 
 
21.  The  TA  may  also  require  input  from  a  reputable  international  institution  or 
professional(s). JICA may assist with the selection of providers and may be consulted for 
information on the short list given its previous involvement in providing training assistance on 
project management and evaluation to the government. The evaluation process will track the 
effectiveness and efficiency of the training program.  
 
22.  The TA will be implemented from October 2012 to October 2014. The TA’s expected 
outcomes will be jointly monitored and evaluated by MEF and ADB during inception, midterm, 
and final review missions, and TA progress will be discussed on a regular basis by utilizing an 
existing portfolio performance forum, such as the regular joint portfolio performance reviews 
organized by ADB and MEF and annual CPRM reviews. 
           
   
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $1,000,000  to  the 
Government of Cambodia to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty 
Reduction for Country Systems in Procurement and Financial Management, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) will require 26 person-
months of international consultant inputs and 48 person-months of national consultant inputs. All 
consultants will be based at the executing agency, Cambodia's Ministry of Economy and Finance. 
 
A.  International consultants 
1.  Procurement Training and Certification Expert (9 person-months, intermittent) 
 
2.  The  overall  objectives  of  the  assignment  are  to  (i)  develop  and  conduct  a  public 
procurement training program for externally financed projects, (ii) develop an interim certification 
program for public procurement professionals and carrying out the certification of the trainees, and 
(iii) develop and conduct a training-of-trainers (TOT) program. Key tasks will include: 
(i)  Design and undertake a rapid training needs assessment taking into account the 
varying levels of procurement capacity within the EA.  
(ii)  Design and prepare training materials for a modular procurement training program 
based on the existing legal framework for public procurement in Cambodia. The 
modules should be suited to the procurement capacity-building needs of project 
managers and procurement officers. 
(iii)  Conduct the training on public procurement for about 60 trainees in the first year 
and 60 trainees in the second year, and to about 10 government officers who will 
serve as trainers. 
(iv)  Develop and conduct a certification system for each module of the training program; 
(v)  Test the delivery of the training program by conducting the first training course 
starting with the basic training module. 
(vi)  In consultation with the Department of Public Procurement, prepare an analysis of 
different  options  to  establish  a  professional  procurement-learning  institute  in 
Cambodia and recommend options on a full certification program for procurement 
professionals. 
 
3.  The expert will be required intermittently for 6 months in the first year and 3 months in the 
second year. The expert will be assisted by a national procurement training expert.  
4.  The qualifications requirements are: (i) a master's degree in engineering, administration, 
finance, or law; or (ii) full membership of an internationally recognized chartered institute relating to 
procurement and/or project management; or (iii) at least 15 years of experience in the field of 
procurement.  The  expert  should  have  at  least  5  years  of  experience  in  designing  modular 
procurement training programs and providing TOT in countries comparable to Cambodia, and must 
have experience in conducting and testing certification programs for procurement professionals in 
at least two projects in the last 10 years. 
 
5.  Reports include (i) an inception report;  (ii) a report at the end of 3 months of services 
summarizing progress in the development of the modular course work, the proposal for the interim 
certification program, and the TOT program; (iii) semiannual reports detailing progress made in all 
the tasks, an evaluation of the effectiveness of the various elements of the capacity-building 
program, and a proposal for midterm corrections; (iv) an annual report (at the end of the first year) 
summarizing the achievements and effectiveness of the training program and the work plan for the 
second year; and (v) a final report summarizing the overall achievements, assessment of the 
outcomes delivered, lessons learned, and recommendations on improving the effectiveness of 
such capacity building programs.

10  Appendix 3 
 
2.  Financial Management Expert (8 person-months, intermittent) 
 
6.  The  overall  objectives  of  the  assignment  are  to  (i)  develop  and  conduct  a  financial 
management training program for externally funded projects, (ii) develop an interim certification 
program for financial management professionals and carry out certification of the trainees, and (iii) 
develop and conduct a training-of-trainers program. Key tasks will include: 
 
(i)  Design and prepare training materials for a modular financial management training 
program  based  on  the  existing  legal  framework  for  financial  management  in 
Cambodia, but also on the guidelines and procedures of key development partners. 
The modules should be suited to the financial management capacity-building needs 
of finance officers. 
(ii)  Provide training on financial management to about 60 trainees in the first year and 
60 trainees in the second year, and to about 15 government officers who will serve 
as trainers. 
(iii)  Develop and conduct a certification system for each module of the training program. 
(iv)  Test the delivery of the training program by conducting the first training course 
starting with the basic training module. 
 
7.  The expert will be required intermittently for 5 months in the first year and 3 months in the 
second year, and will be assisted by a national financial management expert.  
 
8.  The  qualifications  requirements  are  (i)  a  master's  degree  in  administration,  business, 
finance, or law; or (ii) full membership of an internationally recognized chartered institute relating to 
financial management; or (iii) at least 15 years of experience in financial management. The expert 
should have at least 5 years of experience in designing modular financial management training 
programs and providing TOT in countries at a similar level of development as Cambodia, and must 
have  experience  in  conducting  and  testing  certification  programs  for  financial  management 
professionals in at least two projects in the last 10 years. 
 
9.  Reports include (i) an inception report; (ii) a report at the end of 3 months of services 
summarizing progress in the development of the modular course work, the proposal for the interim 
certification program, and the TOT program; (iii) semiannual reports detailing the progress made, 
an evaluation of the effectiveness of the various elements of the capacity building program, and 
proposal for midterm corrections; (iv) an annual report (at the end of the first year) summarizing the 
achievements and the effectiveness of the program, and the work plan for the second year; and 
(v) a final report summarizing the overall achievements, assessment of the outcomes delivered, 
lessons learned, and recommendations on improving the effectiveness. 
 
3.  Project Management Expert (6 person-months, intermittent) 
 
10.  The  overall  objectives  of  the  assignment  are  to  (i)  develop  and  conduct  a  project 
management training program for externally funded projects and (ii) develop an interim certification 
program for project management professionals and carry out certification of the trainees. Key tasks 
will include: 
 
(i)  Design and prepare training materials for a modular project management training 
program  based  on  the  existing  legal  framework  for  project  management  in 
Cambodia, but also on the guidelines and procedures of key development partners. 
The modules should be suited to the project management capacity-building needs 
of the target group of project managers.

Appendix 3  11 
 
(ii)  Provide training on project management to about 60 trainees in the first year and 
60 trainees in the second year. 
(iii)  Provide inputs to the financial management and procurement certification systems. 
(iv)  Test the delivery of the training program by conducting the first training course 
starting with the basic training module. 
 
11.  The expert will be required intermittently for 4 months in the first year and 2 months in the 
second year. 
                                                                                                                                                                                 
12.  The qualifications requirements are (i) a master's degree in engineering, administration, 
business, finance, or law; or (ii) full membership of an internationally recognized chartered institute 
relating to project management. The expert should have at least 15 years of experience in project 
management and must have experience in developing standard operating procedures for the 
selection, management, and implementation of projects and programs, and in conducting training 
on the same, similar to Cambodia's standard operating procedures, and at least 10 years of 
experience in multilateral institutions with extensive knowledge of the complete project cycle. 
 
13.  Reports and deliverables include (i) an inception report;  (ii) a report at the end of 3 months 
of services summarizing progress in the development of the modular course work and the proposal 
for the interim certification program; (iii) semiannual reports to ADB detailing progress made on all 
the tasks, an evaluation of the effectiveness of the various elements of the capacity building 
program and the proposal for midterm corrections; (iv) an annual report at the end of the first year 
of services summarizing the achievements, the effectiveness of the program, and the work plan for 
the second year; and (v) a final report, found acceptable by ADB, that summarizes the overall 
achievements, assessment of the outcomes delivered, lessons learned, and recommendations on 
improving the effectiveness of such a capacity building program. 
 
4.  Training Evaluator Expert (3 person-months, intermittent) 
 
14.  The overall objectives of the assignment are to (i) assess the design of the training modules 
and  provide  recommendations  to  improve  the  modules;  (ii)  evaluate  the  effectiveness  of  the 
training provided considering factors such as on-the-job training and classroom training. Key tasks 
will include: 
 
(i)  Assess if the modules are meeting the project management capacity building needs 
of the target group of project managers, finance officers and procurement officers. 
(ii)  Provide recommendations on strengthening the objectives and implementation of 
the  training  provided.  The  evaluation  should  focus  on  the  following  criteria: 
relevance,  effectiveness,  efficiency,  and  sustainability.  The  assessment  and 
recommendations will be prepared after the conclusion of modules 1 and 2, and 
after modules 3 and 4, in the first year of the TA. 
(iii)  Assess  and  evaluate  if  subsequent  training  modules  in  the  second  year  are 
adequately taking into account the recommendations provided and how the training 
on procurement processing can improve contracts management. 
(iv)  Support the international procurement expert in preparing an analysis of different 
options to establish a professional procurement-learning institute in Cambodia, and 
recommend options on a full certification program for procurement professionals. 
(v)  Support implementation of the project management course and provide a short 
study recommending various options to mainstream project management training 
within government.

12  Appendix 3 
 
15.  The expert will be required intermittently for 2 months in the first year and 1 month in the 
second year. 
 
16.  The qualifications requirements are (i) a master's degree in engineering, administration, 
business, finance, or law; or (ii) full membership of an internationally recognized chartered institute 
relating to project management; or (iii) at least 15 years of experience in project management. The 
expert  must  have  experience  in  procurement,  financial  management,  or  project  management 
training evaluation, preferably in Cambodia. The expert should have experience in transferring 
knowledge from a regional developed member country to Cambodia. 
 
17.  Reports include (i) a report on modules 1 and 2 submitted; (ii) a report on modules 3 and 4 
submitted and found acceptable by ADB; (iii) a report evaluating the program and assessing the 
links between procurement processing and contract management 2 months before the TA closing 
date. 
 
B.  National Consultants 
 
1.  Procurement Training and Certification Expert (12 person-months, intermittent) 
18.  The overall objectives of the assignment are to (i) assist in development and conduct of a 
public procurement training program for externally funded projects, (ii) assist in developing an 
interim certification program for public procurement professionals and carrying out certification of 
the trainees, and (iii) assist in development and conduct of a TOT program. Key tasks will include: 
 
(i)  assisting the international expert in the training needs assessment and the design 
and preparation of training materials for modular procurement training, and 
(ii)  assisting the international expert in all activities and tasks. 
 
19.  The expert will be required intermittently for 7 months in the first year and 5 months in the 
second year. The expert will be guided by an international procurement training expert. 
 
20.  The  qualification  requirements  are  a  bachelor's  degree  in  engineering,  administration, 
business, finance or law; at least 5 years of hands-on experience in the use of Cambodia's 
procurement manual; fluency in English and capability for technical translations from or to Khmer 
and English. In addition, the expert must have experience in conducting training on the use of the 
procurement manual.  
 
2.  Financial Management Expert (12 person-months, intermittent) 
 
21.  The overall objectives of the assignment are to (i) assist in development and conduct of a 
financial management training program for externally funded projects, (ii) assist in developing an 
interim certification program for financial management professionals and carrying out certification 
of the trainees, and (iii) assist in development and conduct of a TOT program. Key tasks will 
include: 
 
(i)  assisting the international expert in the training needs assessment and the design 
and preparation of training materials for modular procurement training, and 
(ii)  assisting the international expert in all activities and tasks.

Appendix 3  13 
 
22.  The expert will be required intermittently for 7 months in the first year and 5 months in the 
second year. The expert will be guided by an international financial management expert. 
 
23.  The  qualification  requirements  are  a  bachelor's  degree  in  engineering,  administration, 
business, finance, or law; at least 5 years of hands-on experience in the use of Cambodia’s 
financial management manual; fluency in English and capability for technical translations from or to 
Khmer and English. In addition, the coordinator must have experience in conducting training 
programs on the use of the financial management manual. 
 
3.   Training Coordinator (24 person-months) 
 
24.  The coordinator will assist in coordinating the overall implementation of the TA, including 
the day-to-day TA administration. The coordinator will be based in the project management office 
of the executing agency and report to the project manager. The coordinator will work closely with 
the executing agency, consultants, suppliers, and training venue providers. The tasks are: 
 
(i)  support and maintain close coordination with government ministries or institutions 
and provide necessary assistance to implement the TA activities, including support 
for participants’ training; 
(ii)  coordinate  with  the  executing  agency  and  consultants  to  determine  training 
programs; 
(iii)  work  with  the  consultants  to  select  participants  and  ensure  that  nominated 
participants meet the criteria; 
(iv)  assist  in  organizing  project  committee  meetings,  including  the  preparation  of 
discussion papers; 
(v)  coordinate with the training venue providers regarding participants’ training;  
(vi)  ensure that inception, progress, and final reports summarizing all achievements and 
activities undertaken during the period are delivered on time; and 
(vii)  undertake  other  relevant  TA  activities  that  may  be  requested  by  ADB  and  the 
executing agency to ensure successful implementation of the TA. 
 
25.  The qualification requirements are a bachelor's degree; at least 3 years of experience in 
processing  and  monitoring  financial  accounts,  preferably  in  development  partner-financed  TA 
activities; experience in organizing training workshops; fluency in English and ability to translate to 
and from Khmer and English. Also required are advanced computer skills with sound knowledge of 
common word-processing, spreadsheet, and graphics software.
